question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned a lot more about the linguistic portion of the Japanese language.
2. I learned how linguistic journals are written about another language in English (which is super helpful if one wants to study another language but publish in the U.S.)
3. I learned how to skim, summarize, and find research gaps in current papers, which allowed me to gain some skills that would be necessary as a future linguist.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned what the field of linguistics is and about the history/current state of research in Japanese linguistics, learned how to identify problems in studies, as well as how to think about and design good studies for the future, learned more about differences between native Japanese speakers and learners as well as identified unconscious/conscious choices these learners make, conducted a study in the field of Japanese linguistics and learned how to deal with problems in study design, research, and data.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: We read a lot of literature on the subject and were asked to critique the papers. While sometimes I had trouble coming up with critiques beyond the usual "the sample size is small" or "the results are not generalizable," I think this overall approach to reading papers allowed us to think critically about how to best set up a research experiment while also recognizing that there is no one-size-fits-all experiment that has no weaknesses.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like the consistency of the course. You read two journal articles every week and practice the same skills. It allows students to acquire the skills necessary to read the papers but also understand them at a steady pace, which some professors ignore. I would definitely keep this part.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You don't have to be a linguistics major to be in this class—reading the papers every week might be really difficult at first, but you will not be the only one struggling with the steep learning curve. But once you get used to it, you'll learn a lot more about the Japanese language than if you only take the Japanese language classes. Plus, you get to do your own research project, which is good experience for any university student.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
- I wish that the professor could have listed all the readings on the syllabus beforehand. I didn't realize the professor didn't until it was too late.  There were only general topics but I had no idea about how much reading was expected of us (more than 100 pages of academic journals per week). The same goes for the collaborative mini projects, which had no due dates, which made it difficult to plan ahead. I did not like how one was due shortly after spring break. Overall, I did not like how the syllabus was not clear. In all my other readings-heavy classes, weekly readings expectations are clearly listed in the syllabus and posted in Sakai beforehand so we have a taste of what we have to read. The professor posted each batch of readings a few weeks before and I had no idea what or how much was expected. 
- I did not enjoy how classes went more than 5 minutes over nearly every single session. 
- I also did not enjoy cold calling.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be warned that you will have to do some research for this class, and if that's not your boat, I wouldn't take it. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that this course would be a good fit for anyone who has any interest in Chinese or linguistics. You don't necessarily need a background in any of them to succeed, because Liu laoshi is willing to help you through it, but I think it helps in being able to understand the concepts faster. I only knew a little Chinese, and I had taken a linguistics course the semester before taking this class, and I think my linguistics knowledge made up for my Chinese knowledge. I think most other people in the class had a bit more background in Chinese but not as much in linguistics, so it depends. However, everyone was able to produce pretty successful research projects by the end of the semester, and there's a place for everyone's interests in the research project! I will say, the course can be a lot of reading at times, and the research project can be time-consuming depending on how you're collecting your data, so I would keep that in mind as you're balancing courses. My biggest takeaway from the course, though, is probably getting to learn more about my friends and their cultural experiences, so I would say that was worth it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take with friends, it's fun

course: AMES-353S-01 : EAST ASIAN LANGUAGES AS L2S.AMES-353S-01.LINGUIST-353S-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how to identify quality language learning activities for East Asian Languages, critically consider literature pertaining to East Asian language acquisition, and design our own studies that can test different questions about East Asian language acquisition.

course: AMES-353S-01 : EAST ASIAN LANGUAGES AS L2S.AMES-353S-01.LINGUIST-353S-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

course: AMES-353S-01 : EAST ASIAN LANGUAGES AS L2S.AMES-353S-01.LINGUIST-353S-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to dissect research papers for linguistics (summary, critiques, as well as propose future studies) while learning several different language phenomena in Korean, Chinese, and Japanese. Lastly, I learned how to analyze my language teacher's teaching pedagogy and learned why they make us do what they do.

course: AMES-353S-01 : EAST ASIAN LANGUAGES AS L2S.AMES-353S-01.LINGUIST-353S-01.

course: AMES-353S-01 : EAST ASIAN LANGUAGES AS L2S.AMES-353S-01.LINGUIST-353S-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to better comprehend Research Papers, and critically think about them (how to improve, what to do later...). I also learned how to better deffend my ideas, beliefs and opinions.

course: AMES-353S-01 : EAST ASIAN LANGUAGES AS L2S.AMES-353S-01.LINGUIST-353S-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to analyze the methodology of studies that investigate the syntax of various speaker groups, and identify common errors in study design. I also learned more about the different tasks that can be used to assess syntax acquisition, such as truth value judgement tasks, and best practices for designing studies that use these tools effectively. Additionally, I learned about different language instruction theories and approaches, and how to integrate the insights thereof to most effectively teach language in the classroom.

course: AMES-353S-01 : EAST ASIAN LANGUAGES AS L2S.AMES-353S-01.LINGUIST-353S-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Price provided a thorough overview of linguistics, covering topics from phonetics to syntax. He facilitated class interaction by assigning group exercises. Additionally, he used real-life examples to analyze phonetics in human speech, and it was particularly fascinating to observe the workings of the human speech apparatus under X-ray. His availability, especially when covering challenging topics, was commendable. As English is my second language, I sometimes struggle with pronouncing specific phonemes. However, thanks to the professor, I not only learned the importance of taking pride in having an accent but also mastered accurate phonetics pronunciation using the IPA chart from York University.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Prior to taking LING211 with Professor Osborne, I thought I knew what a good professor was. Through several good experiences in classes in the past and I had slowly built up a rough framework for categorizing what makes a good professor. However, now that I have finished LING211, I can say without a doubt that not only does Professor Osborne surpass that bar, I think she's ruined Duke professors for me in the future. I don't think anyone else can live up to her gold standard. Not only is she the single nicest professor I've ever had, she goes out of her way to help you succeed in things even outside the class. Whether that includes helping you understand small concepts from class or even discussing the best job opportunities for you specifically, she really cares about her students, in a way that is rarely seen. If you have a chance to take a class with her before you graduate (as most people in her classes are upperclassmen), DO IT. With my time at Duke nearing the end, I can safely say that Professor Osborne was the highlight of my Duke experience. I'm even taking another course with her in the spring, as I cannot bear to go a semester without having her as a teacher.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: A stronger ability to understand and speak Spanish as well as a grasp of numerous Spanish grammar concepts such as pronouns, ser/estar, pretertite/imperfect, nouns and their usages, and more

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned a lot about grammatical constructions in Spanish
I learned some about different philosophies of what language and grammar are

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the reasons behind common grammatical uses, such as the structure of sentences and evaluation of different verb types. I also learned about different uses of adjectives and how certain words change meaning given the context or even verb type associated with it. In addition, I learned about the origin of words and how to find their origins, and how that is most properly used in a sentence.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Knowledge: deeper dives into grammatical concepts (subjunctive, nouns, adjectives)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Examining the origin of words in the Spanish language and tracing them to languages with similarities to Spanish such as Arabic and English. 
- Finding examples of course material in media consumed outside of class i.e music, short stories, podcasts, and videos. 
- Understanding reasons behind grammatical rulings and common misconceptions amongst Spanish learners and natives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the intricacies of Spanish linguistics and grammar, including concepts that I didn’t know existed in English. We dived rigorously into the various applications of linguistic signs, pronouns, concordance, advanced conjugation, subjunctive and imperative moods, expressions and idioms, and many other topics in spoken Spanish language.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: That honorifics are way more complex than indicating just politeness, how to analyze and critique research in linguistics, how to create linguistic experiments, how to teach Japanese language

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned a lot more about the linguistic portion of the Japanese language.
2. I learned how linguistic journals are written about another language in English (which is super helpful if one wants to study another language but publish in the U.S.)
3. I learned how to skim, summarize, and find research gaps in current papers, which allowed me to gain some skills that would be necessary as a future linguist.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: critical evaluation of academic literature, understanding of linguistic pragmatics and nuances in language usage under different contexts, designing research and experimental methods

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned what the field of linguistics is and about the history/current state of research in Japanese linguistics, learned how to identify problems in studies, as well as how to think about and design good studies for the future, learned more about differences between native Japanese speakers and learners as well as identified unconscious/conscious choices these learners make, conducted a study in the field of Japanese linguistics and learned how to deal with problems in study design, research, and data.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: For each class meeting, there is a paper to read in advance to allow for discussion during class time, which facillitated my thinking into how a research might want to conduct a similar experiment with a more grounded motivation and rigorous methodology.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: We read a lot of literature on the subject and were asked to critique the papers. While sometimes I had trouble coming up with critiques beyond the usual "the sample size is small" or "the results are not generalizable," I think this overall approach to reading papers allowed us to think critically about how to best set up a research experiment while also recognizing that there is no one-size-fits-all experiment that has no weaknesses.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like the consistency of the course. You read two journal articles every week and practice the same skills. It allows students to acquire the skills necessary to read the papers but also understand them at a steady pace, which some professors ignore. I would definitely keep this part.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciate the interactive nature of the class, particularly how students have the chance to express their thoughts and critiques in classroom/HW

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The presentations in class were insightful and built well on the readings, the overall structure of the class synthesized all the material very well. Including videos that related to the paper we read was also very interesting.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It challenged the simplified version of honorifics = politeness that Japanese language classes usually teach.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think the class added a component that I wouldn't have learned about in my Japanese classes. For instance, we get more into the why, how, and what of the language choices of L1 and L2 Japanese speakers that's mostly overlooked in my language classes that I appreciate learning about.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Same reasons as above.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: There were lots of insights about Japanese language and usage that I had never considered, and probably most native speakers have never considered before. Thinking about these new insights was particularly helpful for my Japanese language learning from both a perspective of "knowledge of the language" and "knowledge about the language." It was also very interesting to take a deep dive into previous literature and better understand the current state of research/

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Chen sensei is the GOAT, so just go for it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you have learned Japanese before, it's very insightful and gives you context about your learning experience. The class sets you up so that you've read so many papers and you've conducted your own research that you can create a thesis out of it, and Professor Chen is very supportive of this thesis route.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You don't have to be a linguistics major to be in this class—reading the papers every week might be really difficult at first, but you will not be the only one struggling with the steep learning curve. But once you get used to it, you'll learn a lot more about the Japanese language than if you only take the Japanese language classes. Plus, you get to do your own research project, which is good experience for any university student.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
- I wish that the professor could have listed all the readings on the syllabus beforehand. I didn't realize the professor didn't until it was too late.  There were only general topics but I had no idea about how much reading was expected of us (more than 100 pages of academic journals per week). The same goes for the collaborative mini projects, which had no due dates, which made it difficult to plan ahead. I did not like how one was due shortly after spring break. Overall, I did not like how the syllabus was not clear. In all my other readings-heavy classes, weekly readings expectations are clearly listed in the syllabus and posted in Sakai beforehand so we have a taste of what we have to read. The professor posted each batch of readings a few weeks before and I had no idea what or how much was expected. 
- I did not enjoy how classes went more than 5 minutes over nearly every single session. 
- I also did not enjoy cold calling.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be warned that you will have to do some research for this class, and if that's not your boat, I wouldn't take it. However, if you want to experience some linguistic research and you're curious about it, this is a great starter course because we have students from all kinds of background.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that this course would be a good fit for anyone who has any interest in Chinese or linguistics. You don't necessarily need a background in any of them to succeed, because Liu laoshi is willing to help you through it, but I think it helps in being able to understand the concepts faster. I only knew a little Chinese, and I had taken a linguistics course the semester before taking this class, and I think my linguistics knowledge made up for my Chinese knowledge. I think most other people in the class had a bit more background in Chinese but not as much in linguistics, so it depends. However, everyone was able to produce pretty successful research projects by the end of the semester, and there's a place for everyone's interests in the research project! I will say, the course can be a lot of reading at times, and the research project can be time-consuming depending on how you're collecting your data, so I would keep that in mind as you're balancing courses. My biggest takeaway from the course, though, is probably getting to learn more about my friends and their cultural experiences, so I would say that was worth it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take with friends, it's fun

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The knowledge I took away from this course mainly was how connected identity is to language. Not only identity I also learned how the language we use represents parts of cultural background along with language ideologies that introduce social hierarchies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: After taking this course, I have learned that language plays a salient role in identity formation. Before taking this course, I was unaware of the numerous language ideologies in society. Still, this course showed me that these ideologies alter how we interact with others in society. Despite language being a form of communication, there are so many ways people can interact with one another that do not involve a "formal" language. This course has also introduced me to many native languages and language varieties that exist today that I was not aware of previously.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was challenged to think about my identity and the identity of others in relation to language in deep and interesting ways. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to apply semiotics (sign, symbol, index) to different situations and topics. I learned terms like community of practice, style shifting, and pragmatics, among others, that have helped me to give concrete, concise terminology to phenomena I couldn't otherwise describe. I learned about the difference between covert and overt prestige as it relates to communities of practice and language varieties.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of new Spanish vocabulary relating to sociolinguistics and social justice for subordinated indigenous languages. I also learned the skill of reading scholarly linguistics articles carefully and attentively. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Throughout this course, I learned the following:
1) Knowledge about the intersection between linguistic diversity and human rights, in the context of several Spanish-speaking countries and in environments like academia, the workplace, the law, social settings and more
2) Knowledge about the various representations of linguistic discrimination and injustice, and how this affects a variety of communities
3) Knowledge about the history of linguistic rights in various countries, including the development of legislation and projects/movements to support linguistic human rights

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings were intellectually stimulating, but the majority of the class material focused on Mexico and Peru. That's not in and of itself a bad thing, but the class is called "Linguistic Rights in America," so I expected to focus on the U.S. or Latin America as a whole.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The instructor would often voice new viewpoints on the subject of linguistic rights that I had never before considered, and that was stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Prof Paredes does a great job of connecting class conversations from each module, so that students remember previous class material and can make deeper level insights about what they are learning. Another thing that made the class intellectually stimulating was that Prof Paredes included a variety of mechanisms like film, guest speakers, podcasts, etc. for students to engage with the community and themes discussed during class. To make the class more intellectually stimulating, it might have been nice to do some of the cultural events as a class rather than have this be a completely individual/asynchronous assignment.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

Be wary of the communication from the instructor regarding the assignment parameters and deadlines, because those often change and are not clearly conveyed to the students. However, on the positive side, the instructor is very understanding and accommodating in terms of giving extensions and so forth.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I also was able to learn Guarani phrases and bits of other indigenous languages through Patrick Semmler. Lastly, I was able to learn more about the implications of the oficialization of English in the U.S.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I learned a lot about the challenges inherent to language revitalization and the steps and support necessary to successfully revitalize a community's language. This course fostered a lot of discussion, and Profe Paredes imparted so much of her knowledge and experience on us, and I feel much more knowledgeable on the subject than I did previously.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: While I studied public policy throughout my Duke career, I had never taken a deep dive into language policy or looked at how central linguistics was to political structures. I truly gained a new perspective through this course, which was an incredibly rewarding way for me to wrap up my time at Duke. I also had never written an ethnography before and found that experience to be incredibly eye opening - learning that observation is a skill will continue to be instrumental throughout my career. I also had never played a role-playing game as a part of an academic class before, and that was an incredibly helpful opportunity that allowed me to better understand how language construction and change can occur in the world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Overall, I learned about reoccurring patterns around the world. I came in with a pretty Americanized lens that typically did not allow me to recognize the similar patterns of colonization and how the pushed language loss. Additionally the concept of continual loss of language seemed far off, however this class reminded me it is still very prevalent.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical theory, linguistic/sociology research methods, ethnography

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about cognition and the effect of subcortical white matter fiber tracts in aging. I learned how working memory affects consciousness. I learned about embodied cognition and ecological validity.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course touches on the foundations of neuroscience research and neuroimaging, with a particular focus on cognitive reserve. To understand the research, knowledge of how fMRI, EEG, MEG, and CSM were taught, as well as foundational principles like the basis of resting state fMRI and a multimodal theory of the brain. The course also delved into some linguistic theory and conversations about language and consciousness, as well as music and musicianship. A lot of the neuroscience research that we looked at was situated in the context of languaging and musicianship.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The knowledge I took away from this course mainly was how connected identity is to language. Not only identity I also learned how the language we use represents parts of cultural background along with language ideologies that introduce social hierarchies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: After taking this course, I have learned that language plays a salient role in identity formation. Before taking this course, I was unaware of the numerous language ideologies in society. Still, this course showed me that these ideologies alter how we interact with others in society. Despite language being a form of communication, there are so many ways people can interact with one another that do not involve a "formal" language. This course has also introduced me to many native languages and language varieties that exist today that I was not aware of previously.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was challenged to think about my identity and the identity of others in relation to language in deep and interesting ways. We explored diverse populations of many ethnicities, races, social standings and countries to investigate how our language pervades the concept of who we are and how we are perceived.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to apply semiotics (sign, symbol, index) to different situations and topics. I learned terms like community of practice, style shifting, and pragmatics, among others, that have helped me to give concrete, concise terminology to phenomena I couldn't otherwise describe. I learned about the difference between covert and overt prestige as it relates to communities of practice and language varieties.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained knowledge about the class topic (Language & Identity & Constructing Social Hierarchies), I learnt methods of sociolinguistics, and developed ways of thinking about the nature of language.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the reasons behind common grammatical uses, such as the structure of sentences and evaluation of different verb types. I also learned about different uses of adjectives and how certain words change meaning given the context or even verb type associated with it. In addition, I learned about the origin of words and how to find their origins, and how that is most properly used in a sentence.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

- Examining the origin of words in the Spanish language and tracing them to languages with similarities to Spanish such as Arabic and English. 
- Finding examples of course material in media consumed outside of class i.e music, short stories, podcasts, and videos. 
- Understanding reasons behind grammatical rulings and common misconceptions amongst Spanish learners and natives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of new Spanish vocabulary relating to sociolinguistics and social justice for subordinated indigenous languages. I also learned the skill of reading scholarly linguistics articles carefully and attentively. Finally, I learned more about the landscape, specifically in Peru, of the legislation and general attitude in politics around indigenous languages.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Throughout this course, I learned the following:
1) Knowledge about the intersection between linguistic diversity and human rights, in the context of several Spanish-speaking countries and in environments like academia, the workplace, the law, social settings and more
2) Knowledge about the various representations of linguistic discrimination and injustice, and how this affects a variety of communities
3) Knowledge about the history of linguistic rights in various countries, including the development of legislation and projects/movements to support linguistic human rights

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings were intellectually stimulating, but the majority of the class material focused on Mexico and Peru. That's not in and of itself a bad thing, but the class is called "Linguistic Rights in America," so I expected to focus on the U.S. or Latin America as a whole.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

Another thing that made the class intellectually stimulating was that Prof Paredes included a variety of mechanisms like film, guest speakers, podcasts, etc. for students to engage with the community and themes discussed during class. To make the class more intellectually stimulating, it might have been nice to do some of the cultural events as a class rather than have this be a completely individual/asynchronous assignment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I learned a lot about the challenges inherent to language revitalization and the steps and support necessary to successfully revitalize a community's language. This course fostered a lot of discussion, and Profe Paredes imparted so much of her knowledge and experience on us, and I feel much more knowledgeable on the subject than I did previously.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about linguistic human rights from both a theoretical and practical perspective. We learned to think critically about and strengthen our own opinions through debates and in-class conversations. We learned about the importance of indigenous languages for communities.
